Patient has objective, reproducible obstructive ventilatory defect with FEV1/FVC 60% and FEV1 50% predicted that is persistent after bronchodilator, with supportive physiologic evidence of hyperinflation (TLC 110%, RV 115%) and reduced gas transfer (DLCO 60%). Longstanding 36 pack‑year smoking history and absence of alternative cardiopulmonary causes (normal transthoracic echo ruling out left heart failure and elevated pulmonary pressures; normal HRCT, normal chest x‑ray, normal V/Q scan, normal bronchoscopy and VATS wedge biopsies) make smoking‑related COPD (small‑airways predominant/emphysema physiology not visualized on imaging) the most likely diagnosis. Extensive evaluation for malignancy and other systemic causes of weight loss so far (CBC/CMP/thyroid/cortisol/HIV/FIT/age‑appropriate GI evaluation) has been unrevealing; the modest 20 lb weight loss in a patient who remains obese (BMI 31) is most consistent with COPD‑related systemic inflammation and appetite suppression from smoking, though occult malignancy or systemic disease cannot be absolutely excluded.

Confidence: High for smoking‑related COPD as the explanation for the dyspnea; moderate for attributing weight loss solely to COPD (residual uncertainty remains).

How uncertainties were resolved: progressive obstructive physiology with reduced DLCO aligns with smoking‑related airways disease/emphysema despite normal imaging; cardiac causes and pulmonary vascular disease were effectively excluded by echocardiography and V/Q testing; invasive lung tissue sampling (VATS biopsies) and bronchoscopy were nondiagnostic, lowering the likelihood of focal neoplasm or interstitial lung disease. Routine labs and targeted tests for endocrine, infectious, and GI causes of weight loss are normal.

Remaining questions I would clarify with additional time or new findings: if weight loss continues or other systemic signs develop, obtain whole‑body PET‑CT to search for occult malignancy, repeat targeted imaging (CT chest with contrast) in 3–6 months, consider CPET if functional limitation disproportionate to spirometry, and engage oncology/GI/ENT evaluation as clinically indicated.

Recommended management (based on current findings): strong smoking cessation intervention (behavioral support + pharmacotherapy), start long‑acting bronchodilator therapy (LAMA or LABA/LAMA combination) and consider inhaled corticosteroid only if exacerbation history or eosinophils indicate; enroll in pulmonary rehabilitation; assess and optimize nutrition (dietitian referral) and monitor weight trajectory; immunizations per guidelines (influenza, pneumococcal, COVID); consider low‑dose CT lung cancer screening per age/pack‑year criteria if not already enrolled; schedule follow‑up in 4–12 weeks to reassess symptoms and weight and repeat imaging sooner if new symptoms arise.

Rationale for finalizing: The combination of persistent airflow obstruction, hyperinflation, reduced DLCO, heavy smoking history, and exhaustive negative anatomic and invasive testing supports COPD as the primary diagnosis. Given the breadth of negative testing for alternative explanations, further diagnostic yield from additional invasive testing is low unless the clinical picture evolves.
